Award.AwardTitle: On Beyond Sudoku: Pencil Puzzles as an Engaging Problem Domain for Introductory Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project investigates the use of pencil puzzles as a rich and varied source of problems that are interesting to all types of students and can be applied to a wide range of topics throughout the introductory computer science curriculum. Pencil puzzles are puzzles that have been created to be solved on paper by humans through a deductive process. By their very nature, these puzzles have been created to appeal to a wide audience and to be easily understood - the most well-know is Sudoku but there are a plethora of other, less well-known but equally engaging, pencil puzzles. Since they are designed to be solved deductively, they draw solvers in and induce them to think algorithmically. This project studies the use of pencil puzzles to excite freshman computer science students and lead them to an understanding of specific computing content.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the use of pencil puzzles as a content domain for the teaching of introductory computer science. Previous work has shown that providing context can help students become engaged and more easily make connections to CS concepts in early computing courses.  Pencil puzzles, such as sudoku (dozens of other types exist), are designed to be solved by humans with paper and pencil.  Since these puzzles naturally encourage algorithmic thinking and are designed to be easily understood, they are an appealing context for teaching computing. We have used pencil puzzles as the basis for assignments for nearly every topic within standard introductory computing courses, and have delivered such assignments a total of nine times during seven different courses.  With each such assignment, we have collected data on student grades as well as surveying the students to understand how the assignment has impacted them. The surveys asked questions such as how well the students thought the assignment taught them the week’s material, whether they became frustrated, and whether they believed it improved their overall programming skills.

We looked to answer a number of questions about using pencil puzzles for introductory computing. In particular, we wanted to see whether they were effective for student learning, and if they were effective regardless of the gender and prior experience of the student.  These two factors are important to consider as we look to improve diversity in the field - it is important that in an introductory course, the contexts used are ones that are effective for a wide cross-section of students. We were able to show that in all cases, the grades that students achieved as well as the responses to survey questions were independent of student gender, and in nearly all cases, were also independent of the amount of prior computing experience that the student had. We also found that for all but one assignment, the students largely felt that the assignments were valuable in terms of their learning and improving their skills.

Students were also invited to make open-ended comments with each survey. Detailed analysis of these also revealed encouraging results. We created a set of codes to categorize the types of statements that students made, and tested whether any statistical relationships existed between different types of comments. Specifically, we found that in several cases, students who commented that the assignments were difficult were also significantly more likely to voluntarily say that the assignments were valuable for their learning, which is encouraging for further development of this type of assignment. In addition, the frequencies of the different codes were again largely independent of gender and prior experience, reinforcing our outcomes from the non-open-ended survey questions.  We also conducted a series of interviews with instructors and graduate and undergraduate teaching assistants on the effectiveness  of these assignments. These interviews revealed some valuable insights as to how pencil puzzles may be useful for different topics and for different groups of students, in particular which students may thrive and which may struggle, both for puzzle-based assignments and in the field in general. We will continue our work to help the community at large deliver introductory material in a way that can help all students learn and thrive.
